admreg: Europe and Central Asia,Europe and Central Asia
trustfund:
TF023968-GEF1 - GEORGIA : PROTECTED
            AREAS DEVELOPMENT PROJECT,TF039352-GEORGIA -  PROTECTED AREAS DEV. PROJECT,TF038117-GEORGIA BIODIVERSITY PROJECT,TF038053-GEORGIA - BIODIVERSITY,TF037684-ECA REGION - INDUSTRIAL
            POLLUTION, ETC.,TF037610-GEORGIA - BIODIVERSITY,TF020446-GEF1:PROTECTED AREAS DEVELOPMENT

abstracts.cdata!:
The Protected Areas Development Project
            will conserve biodiversity in Georgia, through the creation
            of three ecologically, and socially sustainable protected
            areas in forest ecosystems, and, build capacity for
            mainstreaming biodiversity conservation into production
            landscapes. The main components will: 1) support the
            development of a detailed plan for biodiversity, and forest
            conservation in the Central Caucasus region, and, support
            corridor conservation planning in Eastern Georgia.
            Biodiversity studies will be financed, and, a policy/legal
            framework will rationalize the mandates of the Framework Law
            on Protected Areas, and the Forest Code for the Central
            Caucasus; communal vegetation types, and rapid biological
            assessments will be mapped to implement corridor plans in
            the Eastern Caucasus Mountains; 2) establish protected areas
            management, and, build awareness of biodiversity
            conservation. Monitoring, and applied research will guide
            park management, and evaluate results of management actions,
            through the development of an information base, livestock
            assessments, and through special studies focused on species,
            plants, and animals to improve management decision-making.
            Training on protected areas management planning will be
            provided, to enforce ranger practices, and, enhance business
            planning; 3) reorganize, and strengthen the Department of
            Protected Areas, through: training in park administration;
            revenue account management; technical training in protected
            areas, and resource management; and, monitoring biodiversity
            programs; and, 4) finance project management, and operating
            costs within the Department of Protected Areas.
